questions.question: According to the AI policy, which of the following uses of generative AI is ALLOWED?
options: Using AI to look up programming concepts or syntax, similar to using documentation
Using GitHub Copilot to write code for a tutorial
Using ChatGPT to generate a helper function for your homework assignment
Using AI to generate code that you then modify and submit
questions.explanation: You may use generative AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT) as a reference, similar to documentation or a textbook. This includes looking up programming concepts or syntax, getting explanations of how functions work, understanding error messages, and learning best practices. However, you must write all submitted code yourself.

questions.question: What is the rule of thumb for determining if your use of AI is permitted?
options: If you understand the AI-generated code, it's allowed
If you could not reasonably reproduce the solution without referring back to the AI's output, then the use is not permitted
If the AI tool is free to use, it's allowed
If you modify the AI-generated code, it's allowed
questions.explanation: The rule of thumb states: If you could not reasonably reproduce the solution without referring back to the AI's output, then the use is not permitted. This helps you determine whether your use of AI crosses the line from reference to code generation.

questions.question: What must you do with AI-powered code completion features in your code editor (like GitHub Copilot, Cursor, Tabnine) when working on course assignments?
options: You can use them for tutorials but not homework
You can use them if you understand the generated code
You must disable them completely
You can use them as long as you only accept a few suggestions
questions.explanation: You must disable AI-powered code completion and generation features in your code editor (e.g., GitHub Copilot, Copilot Chat, Cursor, Tabnine, Codeium) while working on course assignments. Accidental use still counts as a violation, even if you only accept a few suggestions.

questions.question: What happens if you unintentionally violate the AI policy and contact the instructor BEFORE submitting the assignment?
options: The issue can often be resolved in a learning-focused way without triggering formal penalties
You automatically receive a grade of 0 on the assignment
No action is taken
You receive a grade of F in the course
questions.explanation: If you believe you may have violated this policy unintentionally, or you are unsure whether a particular use of AI crossed the line, you must contact the instructor before submitting the assignment. In many cases, early and honest disclosure allows resolution in a learning-focused way (such as revising the work or completing an alternative assignment) without triggering formal penalties.

questions.question: According to the AI policy, which of the following is NOT allowed?
options: Using AI to generate any assignment-specific code, including small snippets or helper functions
Using AI to understand error messages
Using AI to get explanations of how functions work
Using AI to look up programming concepts
questions.explanation: You may not use generative AI tools to generate any assignment-specific code, including small snippets, helper functions, or scaffolding. You also cannot use AI to solve coding exercises, write functions/components, or provide solutions that you then modify and submit.

questions.question: What is the late policy for homework assignments?
options: Late homework is accepted with a 10% penalty, no time limit
Late homework is not accepted under any circumstances
Late homework is accepted with no penalty if you contact the instructor first
Late homework is accepted within 2 weeks with a 20% penalty, but no work is accepted beyond 14 days
questions.explanation: Homework assignments must be submitted before the due time. Late work will be accepted within 2 weeks of the due date/time, with a 20% late penalty. No homework will be accepted beyond the 14 day cutoff.

questions.question: What is the late policy for tutorials?
options: Late tutorials are accepted with a 20% penalty
Late tutorials are accepted with no penalty if you contact the instructor
Late tutorials are not accepted
Late tutorials are accepted with a 10% penalty within 1 week
questions.explanation: Tutorials are due at the midnight following the next class meeting. For instance, if the tutorial was assigned on Friday, it is due at midnight the following Monday unless otherwise specified. The syllabus explicitly states: 'I do not accept late tutorials.'

questions.question: When are tutorials due?
options: At the midnight following the next class meeting
At the same time as homework assignments
One week after they are assigned
At midnight on the day they are assigned
questions.explanation: Tutorials are due at the midnight following the next class meeting. For example, if a tutorial is assigned on Friday, it is due at midnight the following Monday unless otherwise specified.

questions.question: If you are unsure whether your use of AI crosses the line, what should you do?
options: Only use AI for small parts of the code
Contact the instructor before submitting the assignment
Submit the assignment anyway and hope for the best
Use the AI but don't mention it
questions.explanation: If you are unsure whether a particular use of AI crossed the line, you must contact the instructor before submitting the assignment. Early and honest disclosure allows for learning-focused resolution without triggering formal penalties. The syllabus states: 'If you are unsure, ask. Reaching out early is always the better option.'

questions.question: The disclosure pathway for unintentional AI violations does NOT apply to which of the following?
options: Cases where you're unsure if you crossed the line
Early disclosure of potential violations
Intentional misuse of AI tools
Unintentional violations disclosed before submission
questions.explanation: The disclosure pathway does not apply to cases of intentional misuse, repeated violations, or undisclosed AI use discovered after submission. Once an assignment is submitted, any undisclosed violations will be handled according to the enforcement policy.

questions.question: According to the AI policy, what is the key principle about code submission?
options: You can use AI to generate code as long as you cite it
AI-generated code is allowed for tutorials but not homework
All code you submit must be your own
All code must be written by you, but you can use AI-generated code if you understand it
questions.explanation: The fundamental principle is that all code you submit must be your own. Copying, pasting, or adapting AI-generated code is considered academic dishonesty. AI may help you understand code, but you must write all submitted code yourself.

questions.question: How many class sessions can you miss without a grade penalty?
options: Four
One
Three
Two
questions.explanation: You may miss three class sessions -- no questions asked -- without a grade penalty. Any additional absences (beyond the three 'freebies') will impact your participation grade.

questions.question: What happens if you accept just a few AI code suggestions from your editor's Copilot feature?
options: It's only a violation if you accept more than 5 suggestions
It's allowed for tutorials but not homework
It counts as a violation, even if accidental
It's fine as long as you understand the code
questions.explanation: Accidental use still counts as a violation, even if you only accept a few suggestions. You must disable AI-powered code completion features in your code editor while working on course assignments. It is your responsibility to ensure these features are turned off before beginning work.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the AI policy according to the syllabus?
options: To test students' ability to use AI tools effectively
To make assignments more difficult
To build foundational programming skills and prevent over-reliance on AI-generated code
To prevent students from using any technology
questions.explanation: This course is designed to build foundational programming skills, especially functional and event-driven programming. While generative AI tools can be useful for learning, over-reliance on AI-generated code can weaken these skills and make later courses more difficult. The policy sets clear boundaries for appropriate AI use.

questions.question: If you are struggling with an assignment, what should you do according to the AI policy section?
options: Copy code from Stack Overflow
Submit the assignment late
Reach out to the instructor or attend office hours
Use AI to generate the solution
questions.explanation: If you are stuck or confused, please reach out or attend office hours. The policy exists to support your learning -- not to catch mistakes -- but it will be enforced to protect the integrity of your education.

questions.question: What percentage of your final grade comes from exams?
questions.explanation: Exams account for 35% of your final grade. The breakdown is: Attendance & Participation (10%), Tutorials (20%), Exams (35%), and Homework (35%).
